trans-unit.source: Azure Backup FAQ | Microsoft Azure
trans-unit.target: Azure Backup FAQ | Microsoft Azure

trans-unit.source: Frequently asked questions on the Azure Backup service
trans-unit.target: Frequently asked questions on the Azure Backup service

trans-unit.source: Azure Backup - FAQ
trans-unit.target: Azure Backup - FAQ

trans-unit.source: The following is a list of commonly asked questions about Azure Backup.
trans-unit.target: The following is a list of commonly asked questions about Azure Backup.

trans-unit.source: If you have any additional questions about Azure Backup, please go to the the [discussion forum](https://social.msdn.microsoft.com/forums/azure/home?forum=windowsazureonlinebackup) and post your questions.
trans-unit.target: If you have any additional questions about Azure Backup, please go to the the [discussion forum](https://social.msdn.microsoft.com/forums/azure/home?forum=windowsazureonlinebackup) and post your questions.

trans-unit.source: Someone from our community will help you get your answers.
trans-unit.target: Someone from our community will help you get your answers.

trans-unit.source: If a question is commonly asked, we will add it to this article so that it can be found quickly and easily.
trans-unit.target: If a question is commonly asked, we will add it to this article so that it can be found quickly and easily.

trans-unit.source: Installation & Configuration
trans-unit.target: Installation & Configuration

trans-unit.source: **Q1. What is the list of supported operating systems from which I can backup to Azure using Azure Backup?**
trans-unit.target: **Q1. What is the list of supported operating systems from which I can backup to Azure using Azure Backup?**

trans-unit.source: The following list of operating systems is supported by Azure Backup
trans-unit.target: The following list of operating systems is supported by Azure Backup

trans-unit.target: Operating System

trans-unit.target: Platform

trans-unit.target: SKU

trans-unit.target: Windows 8 and latest SPs

trans-unit.target: 64 bit

trans-unit.target: Enterprise, Pro

trans-unit.target: Windows 7 and latest SPs

trans-unit.target: Windows 8.1 and latest SPs

trans-unit.source: **Q2. Where can I download the latest Azure Backup agent?**
trans-unit.target: **Q2. Where can I download the latest Azure Backup agent?**

trans-unit.source: You can download the latest agent from [here](http://aka.ms/azurebackup_agent).
trans-unit.target: You can download the latest agent from [here](http://aka.ms/azurebackup_agent).

trans-unit.source: This can be installed on Windows Server, SCDPM server or Windows client
trans-unit.target: This can be installed on Windows Server, SCDPM server or Windows client

trans-unit.source: **Q3. Which version of SCDPM server is supported?**
trans-unit.target: **Q3. Which version of SCDPM server is supported?**

trans-unit.source: We recommend that you install the [latest](http://aka.ms/azurebackup_agent) Azure Backup agent on the latest update rollup of SCDPM (UR6 as of July 2015)
trans-unit.target: We recommend that you install the [latest](http://aka.ms/azurebackup_agent) Azure Backup agent on the latest update rollup of SCDPM (UR6 as of July 2015)

trans-unit.source: **Q4. When configuring the Azure Backup agent, I am prompted to enter the “vault credentials”. Is there any expiration date attached to the vault credentials?**
trans-unit.target: **Q4. When configuring the Azure Backup agent, I am prompted to enter the “vault credentials”. Is there any expiration date attached to the vault credentials?**

trans-unit.source: Yes, the vault credential expire after 48hours.
trans-unit.target: Yes, the vault credential expire after 48hours.

trans-unit.source: If the file expires, log in to the Azure portal and download the vault credentials files from your Backup vault.
trans-unit.target: If the file expires, log in to the Azure portal and download the vault credentials files from your Backup vault.

trans-unit.source: **Q5. Is there any limit on the number of backup vaults that can be created in each Azure subscription?**
trans-unit.target: **Q5. Is there any limit on the number of backup vaults that can be created in each Azure subscription?**

trans-unit.source: Yes.
trans-unit.target: Yes.

trans-unit.source: As of July 2015, you can create 25 vaults per subscription.
trans-unit.target: As of July 2015, you can create 25 vaults per subscription.

trans-unit.source: If you need more vaults, then create a new subscription.
trans-unit.target: If you need more vaults, then create a new subscription.

trans-unit.source: **Q6. Should I look at a vault as a billing entity?**
trans-unit.target: **Q6. Should I look at a vault as a billing entity?**

trans-unit.source: Though it is possible to get a detailed bill for each vault, we highly recommend that you consider an Azure subscription as a billing entity.
trans-unit.target: Though it is possible to get a detailed bill for each vault, we highly recommend that you consider an Azure subscription as a billing entity.

trans-unit.source: It is consistent across all services and is easier to manage.
trans-unit.target: It is consistent across all services and is easier to manage.

trans-unit.source: **Q7. Are there any limits on the number of servers/machines that can be registered against each vault?**
trans-unit.target: **Q7. Are there any limits on the number of servers/machines that can be registered against each vault?**

trans-unit.source: Yes, you can register upto 50 machines per vault.
trans-unit.target: Yes, you can register upto 50 machines per vault.

trans-unit.source: If you need to register more machines, create a new vault.
trans-unit.target: If you need to register more machines, create a new vault.

trans-unit.source: **Q8. Are there any limits on the amount of data that can be backed up from a Windows server/client or SCDPM server?**
trans-unit.target: **Q8. Are there any limits on the amount of data that can be backed up from a Windows server/client or SCDPM server?**

trans-unit.source: No.
trans-unit.target: No.

trans-unit.source: **Q9. How do I register my server to another datacenter?**
trans-unit.target: **Q9. How do I register my server to another datacenter?**

trans-unit.source: In general the backup data is sent to the datacenter of the Backup Service to which it is registered.
trans-unit.target: In general the backup data is sent to the datacenter of the Backup Service to which it is registered.

trans-unit.source: The easiest way to change the datacenter is to uninstall the agent and reinstall the agent and register to a new datacenter.
trans-unit.target: The easiest way to change the datacenter is to uninstall the agent and reinstall the agent and register to a new datacenter.

trans-unit.source: **Q10. What happens if I rename a Windows server that is backing up data to Azure?**
trans-unit.target: **Q10. What happens if I rename a Windows server that is backing up data to Azure?**

trans-unit.source: Any currently configured backups will be stopped.
trans-unit.target: Any currently configured backups will be stopped.

trans-unit.source: You will need to reregister the server with the backup vault and it will be considered a new server by Recovery Services, so the first backup operation that occurs after registration will be a full backup of all of the data included in the backup instead of just the changes since the last backup occurred.
trans-unit.target: You will need to reregister the server with the backup vault and it will be considered a new server by Recovery Services, so the first backup operation that occurs after registration will be a full backup of all of the data included in the backup instead of just the changes since the last backup occurred.

trans-unit.source: However, if you need to perform a recovery operation you can recover the data that has been backed up using Recover from another server recovery option.
trans-unit.target: However, if you need to perform a recovery operation you can recover the data that has been backed up using Recover from another server recovery option.

trans-unit.source: For more information, see Rename a server.
trans-unit.target: For more information, see Rename a server.

trans-unit.source: **Q11. What types of drives can I backup files and folders from?**
trans-unit.target: **Q11. What types of drives can I backup files and folders from?**

trans-unit.source: The following set of drives/volumes can't be backup:
trans-unit.target: The following set of drives/volumes can't be backup:

trans-unit.source: Removable Media: The drive must report as a fixed to be used a backup item source.
trans-unit.target: Removable Media: The drive must report as a fixed to be used a backup item source.

trans-unit.source: Read-only Volumes: The volume must be writable for the volume shadow copy service (VSS) to function.
trans-unit.target: Read-only Volumes: The volume must be writable for the volume shadow copy service (VSS) to function.

trans-unit.source: Offline Volumes: The volume must be online for VSS to function.
trans-unit.target: Offline Volumes: The volume must be online for VSS to function.

trans-unit.source: Network share: The volume must be local to the server to be backed up using online backup.
trans-unit.target: Network share: The volume must be local to the server to be backed up using online backup.

trans-unit.source: Bitlocker protected volumes: The volume must be unlocked before the backup can occur.
trans-unit.target: Bitlocker protected volumes: The volume must be unlocked before the backup can occur.

trans-unit.source: File System Identification: NTFS is the only file system supported for this version of the online backup service.
trans-unit.target: File System Identification: NTFS is the only file system supported for this version of the online backup service.

trans-unit.source: **Q12. What file and folder types can I back up from my server?**
trans-unit.target: **Q12. What file and folder types can I back up from my server?**

trans-unit.source: The following types are supported:
trans-unit.target: The following types are supported:

trans-unit.source: Encrypted
trans-unit.target: Encrypted

trans-unit.source: Compressed
trans-unit.target: Compressed

trans-unit.source: Sparse
trans-unit.target: Sparse

trans-unit.source: Compressed + Sparse
trans-unit.target: Compressed + Sparse

trans-unit.source: Hard Links: Not supported, skipped
trans-unit.target: Hard Links: Not supported, skipped

trans-unit.source: Reparse Point: Not supported, skipped
trans-unit.target: Reparse Point: Not supported, skipped

trans-unit.source: Encrypted + Compressed: Not supported, skipped
trans-unit.target: Encrypted + Compressed: Not supported, skipped

trans-unit.source: Encrypted + Sparse: Not supported, skipped
trans-unit.target: Encrypted + Sparse: Not supported, skipped

trans-unit.source: Compressed Stream: Not supported, skipped
trans-unit.target: Compressed Stream: Not supported, skipped

trans-unit.source: Sparse Stream: Not supported, skipped
trans-unit.target: Sparse Stream: Not supported, skipped

trans-unit.source: **Q13. What's the minimum size requirement for the cache folder?**
trans-unit.target: **Q13. What's the minimum size requirement for the cache folder?**

trans-unit.source: The size of the cache folder is determined by the amount of data that you are backing up.
trans-unit.target: The size of the cache folder is determined by the amount of data that you are backing up.

trans-unit.source: In general you should expect that 10-15% of the space required for data storage should be allocated for the cache folder.
trans-unit.target: In general you should expect that 10-15% of the space required for data storage should be allocated for the cache folder.

trans-unit.source: **Q14. How can I isolate specific server data from being recovered by other servers in my organization?**
trans-unit.target: **Q14. How can I isolate specific server data from being recovered by other servers in my organization?**

trans-unit.source: Any servers that are registered using the same vault will be able to recover the data backed up by other servers that use the same passphrase.
trans-unit.target: Any servers that are registered using the same vault will be able to recover the data backed up by other servers that use the same passphrase.

trans-unit.source: If you have servers that you want to ensure recovery only occurs to specific servers in your organization, you should use a separate passphrase designated for those servers.
trans-unit.target: If you have servers that you want to ensure recovery only occurs to specific servers in your organization, you should use a separate passphrase designated for those servers.

trans-unit.source: For example, human resources servers could use one encryption passphrase, accounting servers another, and storage servers a third.
trans-unit.target: For example, human resources servers could use one encryption passphrase, accounting servers another, and storage servers a third.

trans-unit.source: **Q15. Can I “migrate” my backup data between subscriptions?**
trans-unit.target: **Q15. Can I “migrate” my backup data between subscriptions?**

trans-unit.source: A15: No
trans-unit.target: A15: No

trans-unit.source: **Q16. Can I “migrate” my backup vault between subscriptions?**
trans-unit.target: **Q16. Can I “migrate” my backup vault between subscriptions?**

trans-unit.source: A16: No.
trans-unit.target: A16: No.

trans-unit.source: The vault is created at a subscription level and cannot be reassigned to another subscription once it’s created.
trans-unit.target: The vault is created at a subscription level and cannot be reassigned to another subscription once it’s created.

trans-unit.source: **Q17. Does the Azure Backup Agent work on a server that uses Windows Server 2012 deduplication?**
trans-unit.target: **Q17. Does the Azure Backup Agent work on a server that uses Windows Server 2012 deduplication?**

trans-unit.source: A17: Yes.
trans-unit.target: A17: Yes.

trans-unit.source: The agent service converts the deduplicated data to normal data when it prepares the backup operation.
trans-unit.target: The agent service converts the deduplicated data to normal data when it prepares the backup operation.

trans-unit.source: It then optimizes the data for backup, encrypts the data and then sends the encrypted data to the online backup service.
trans-unit.target: It then optimizes the data for backup, encrypts the data and then sends the encrypted data to the online backup service.

trans-unit.source: **Q18. Does the backup data get deleted if I cancel a backup after it has started?**
trans-unit.target: **Q18. Does the backup data get deleted if I cancel a backup after it has started?**

trans-unit.source: A18: No.
trans-unit.target: A18: No.

trans-unit.source: The backup vault stores the backed up data that had been transferred up to the point of the cancellation.
trans-unit.target: The backup vault stores the backed up data that had been transferred up to the point of the cancellation.

trans-unit.source: Azure Backup uses a checkpoint mechanism so that the backup data gets check-pointed occasionally during the backup and the next backup process can validate the integrity of the files.
trans-unit.target: Azure Backup uses a checkpoint mechanism so that the backup data gets check-pointed occasionally during the backup and the next backup process can validate the integrity of the files.

trans-unit.source: The next backup triggered would be incremental over the data that had been backed up previously.
trans-unit.target: The next backup triggered would be incremental over the data that had been backed up previously.

trans-unit.source: This provides better utilization of bandwidth, so that you do not need to transfer the same data repeatedly.
trans-unit.target: This provides better utilization of bandwidth, so that you do not need to transfer the same data repeatedly.

trans-unit.source: **Q19. Why am I seeing the warning "Azure Backups have not been configured for this server" even though I had scheduled regular backups previously?**
trans-unit.target: **Q19. Why am I seeing the warning "Azure Backups have not been configured for this server" even though I had scheduled regular backups previously?**

trans-unit.source: A19: This can occur when the backup schedule settings stored on the local server are not the same as the settings stored in the backup vault.
trans-unit.target: A19: This can occur when the backup schedule settings stored on the local server are not the same as the settings stored in the backup vault.

trans-unit.source: When either the server or the settings have been recovered to a known good state, the backup schedules can lose synchronization.
trans-unit.target: When either the server or the settings have been recovered to a known good state, the backup schedules can lose synchronization.

trans-unit.source: If this has happened, you should reconfigure the backup policy and then **Run Back Up Now** to resynchronize the local server with Azure.
trans-unit.target: If this has happened, you should reconfigure the backup policy and then **Run Back Up Now** to resynchronize the local server with Azure.

trans-unit.source: **Q20. What firewall rules are to be configured for backup of Azure Backup?**
trans-unit.target: **Q20. What firewall rules are to be configured for backup of Azure Backup?**

trans-unit.source: Ensure firewall rules enable communication with URLs below for seamless backup of on-premises to Azure and workload protection on Azure:
trans-unit.target: Ensure firewall rules enable communication with URLs below for seamless backup of on-premises to Azure and workload protection on Azure:

trans-unit.source: www.msftncsi.com
trans-unit.target: www.msftncsi.com

trans-unit.source: \*.Microsoft.com
trans-unit.target: \*.Microsoft.com

trans-unit.source: \*.WindowsAzure.com
trans-unit.target: \*.WindowsAzure.com

trans-unit.source: \*.microsoftonline.com
trans-unit.target: \*.microsoftonline.com

trans-unit.source: \*.windows.net
trans-unit.target: \*.windows.net

trans-unit.source: Backup & Retention
trans-unit.target: Backup & Retention

trans-unit.source: **Q1. Is there a limit on the size of each data source being backed up?**
trans-unit.target: **Q1. Is there a limit on the size of each data source being backed up?**

trans-unit.source: As of August 2015, The maximum size of data source is as mentioned below for various operating systems
trans-unit.target: As of August 2015, The maximum size of data source is as mentioned below for various operating systems

trans-unit.source: S.No
trans-unit.target: S.No

trans-unit.source: Operating system
trans-unit.target: Operating system

trans-unit.source: Maximum size of data source
trans-unit.target: Maximum size of data source

trans-unit.source: Windows Server 2012 or above
trans-unit.target: Windows Server 2012 or above

trans-unit.source: Windows Server 8 or above
trans-unit.target: Windows Server 8 or above

trans-unit.source: Windows Server 2008, Windows Server 2008 R2
trans-unit.target: Windows Server 2008, Windows Server 2008 R2

trans-unit.source: Windows 7
trans-unit.target: Windows 7

trans-unit.source: The datasource size is measured as mentioned below
trans-unit.target: The datasource size is measured as mentioned below

trans-unit.source: Datasource
trans-unit.target: Datasource

trans-unit.source: Details
trans-unit.target: Details

trans-unit.source: Volume
trans-unit.target: Volume

trans-unit.source: The amount of data being backed up from single volume of a machine.
trans-unit.target: The amount of data being backed up from single volume of a machine.

trans-unit.source: This is applicable for the volumes being protected on both server and client machines.
trans-unit.target: This is applicable for the volumes being protected on both server and client machines.

trans-unit.source: Hyper-V virtual machine
trans-unit.target: Hyper-V virtual machine

trans-unit.source: Sum of data of all the VHDs of the virtual machine being backed up
trans-unit.target: Sum of data of all the VHDs of the virtual machine being backed up

trans-unit.source: Microsoft SQL Server database
trans-unit.target: Microsoft SQL Server database

trans-unit.source: Size of single SQL database size being backed up
trans-unit.target: Size of single SQL database size being backed up

trans-unit.source: Microsoft SharePoint
trans-unit.target: Microsoft SharePoint

trans-unit.source: Sum of the content and config databases within a SharePoint farm being backed up
trans-unit.target: Sum of the content and config databases within a SharePoint farm being backed up

trans-unit.source: Microsoft Exchange
trans-unit.target: Microsoft Exchange

trans-unit.source: Sum of all Exchange databases in an Exchange server being backed up
trans-unit.target: Sum of all Exchange databases in an Exchange server being backed up

trans-unit.source: BMR/System State
trans-unit.target: BMR/System State

trans-unit.source: Each individual copy of BMR or system state of the machine being backed up
trans-unit.target: Each individual copy of BMR or system state of the machine being backed up

trans-unit.source: **Q2. Is there are limit on the number of times backup can be scheduled per day?**
trans-unit.target: **Q2. Is there are limit on the number of times backup can be scheduled per day?**

trans-unit.source: Yes, Azure Backup enables 3 backup copies per day through Windows Server/Client and 2 backup copies per day through SCDPM.
trans-unit.target: Yes, Azure Backup enables 3 backup copies per day through Windows Server/Client and 2 backup copies per day through SCDPM.

trans-unit.source: **Q3. Is there a difference between DPM’s and Azure Backup’s (i.e on Windows Server without DPM) backup scheduling policy?**
trans-unit.target: **Q3. Is there a difference between DPM’s and Azure Backup’s (i.e on Windows Server without DPM) backup scheduling policy?**

trans-unit.source: Yes.
trans-unit.target: Yes.

trans-unit.source: Using DPM, you can specify daily, weekly, monthly, yearly scheduling while from a Windows Server (without DPM), you can specify only daily, weekly schedules.
trans-unit.target: Using DPM, you can specify daily, weekly, monthly, yearly scheduling while from a Windows Server (without DPM), you can specify only daily, weekly schedules.

trans-unit.source: **Q4. Is there a difference between DPM’s and Azure Backup’s (i.e on Windows Server without DPM) retention policy?**
trans-unit.target: **Q4. Is there a difference between DPM’s and Azure Backup’s (i.e on Windows Server without DPM) retention policy?**

trans-unit.source: No, you have the same capabilities.
trans-unit.target: No, you have the same capabilities.

trans-unit.source: You can specify daily, weekly, monthly and yearly retention policies.
trans-unit.target: You can specify daily, weekly, monthly and yearly retention policies.

trans-unit.source: **Q5. Can I configure my retention policies selectively – i.e. configure weekly and daily but not yearly and monthly?**
trans-unit.target: **Q5. Can I configure my retention policies selectively – i.e. configure weekly and daily but not yearly and monthly?**

trans-unit.source: You have the full set of knobs to come up with policies which best define your compliance/retention requirements.
trans-unit.target: You have the full set of knobs to come up with policies which best define your compliance/retention requirements.

trans-unit.source: **Q6. Can I “schedule a backup” at 6pm and specify “retention policies” at a different time?**
trans-unit.target: **Q6. Can I “schedule a backup” at 6pm and specify “retention policies” at a different time?**

trans-unit.source: No.
trans-unit.target: No.

trans-unit.source: Retention policies can only be applied on backup points.
trans-unit.target: Retention policies can only be applied on backup points.

trans-unit.source: In the below image, the retention policy is being specified on backups taken at 12am and 6pm.
trans-unit.target: In the below image, the retention policy is being specified on backups taken at 12am and 6pm.

trans-unit.source: Schedule Backup and Retention
trans-unit.target: Schedule Backup and Retention

trans-unit.source: **Q7. Is an incremental copy transferred for the retention policies scheduled?**
trans-unit.target: **Q7. Is an incremental copy transferred for the retention policies scheduled?**

trans-unit.source: No, the incremental copy is sent based on the time mentioned in the backup schedule page.
trans-unit.target: No, the incremental copy is sent based on the time mentioned in the backup schedule page.

trans-unit.source: The points that can be retained are determined based on the retention policy.
trans-unit.target: The points that can be retained are determined based on the retention policy.

trans-unit.source: **Q8. If backup is retained for a long duration, does it take a significant time to recover the data (say the oldest point)?**
trans-unit.target: **Q8. If backup is retained for a long duration, does it take a significant time to recover the data (say the oldest point)?**

trans-unit.source: No – the time taken to recovery the oldest or the latest point is one and the same.
trans-unit.target: No – the time taken to recovery the oldest or the latest point is one and the same.

trans-unit.source: Each recovery point behaves like a full point.
trans-unit.target: Each recovery point behaves like a full point.

trans-unit.source: **Q9. If each recovery point is like a full point, does it impact the total billable backup storage?**
trans-unit.target: **Q9. If each recovery point is like a full point, does it impact the total billable backup storage?**

trans-unit.source: Typical long term retention point products store backup data as full points.
trans-unit.target: Typical long term retention point products store backup data as full points.

trans-unit.source: However, these are storage inefficient but are easier and faster to restore.
trans-unit.target: However, these are storage inefficient but are easier and faster to restore.

trans-unit.source: Incremental copies are storage efficient but require you to restore a chain of data which impacts your recovery time.
trans-unit.target: Incremental copies are storage efficient but require you to restore a chain of data which impacts your recovery time.

trans-unit.source: Azure Backup’s unique storage architecture gives you the best of both worlds by optimally storing data for fast restores and incurring low storage costs.
trans-unit.target: Azure Backup’s unique storage architecture gives you the best of both worlds by optimally storing data for fast restores and incurring low storage costs.

trans-unit.source: This approach ensures that your (ingress and egress) bandwidth is efficiently used, storage is kept to the minimum and the time taken to recover is kept to the minimum.
trans-unit.target: This approach ensures that your (ingress and egress) bandwidth is efficiently used, storage is kept to the minimum and the time taken to recover is kept to the minimum.

trans-unit.source: **Q10. Is there a limit on the number of recovery points that can be created?**
trans-unit.target: **Q10. Is there a limit on the number of recovery points that can be created?**

trans-unit.source: As of April 2015, you can have upto 366 recovery points.
trans-unit.target: As of April 2015, you can have upto 366 recovery points.

trans-unit.source: You can use any permutation to arrive at a number which is less than 366.
trans-unit.target: You can use any permutation to arrive at a number which is less than 366.

trans-unit.source: Eg – the retention points in the below picture add to 354.
trans-unit.target: Eg – the retention points in the below picture add to 354.

trans-unit.source: Retention screen
trans-unit.target: Retention screen

trans-unit.source: **Q11. Once Microsoft improves the limit from 366, will I need to upgrade the agent or reseed the initial backup?**
trans-unit.target: **Q11. Once Microsoft improves the limit from 366, will I need to upgrade the agent or reseed the initial backup?**

trans-unit.source: No.
trans-unit.target: No.

trans-unit.source: Once we make the change in our service, you will be notified through our social media outlets (blogs, Azure announcements, portal etc).
trans-unit.target: Once we make the change in our service, you will be notified through our social media outlets (blogs, Azure announcements, portal etc).

trans-unit.source: Based on your needs, you would then be required to only change the retention policy.
trans-unit.target: Based on your needs, you would then be required to only change the retention policy.

trans-unit.source: **Q12. Why is the amount of data transferred in backup not equal to the amount of data I backed up?**
trans-unit.target: **Q12. Why is the amount of data transferred in backup not equal to the amount of data I backed up?**

trans-unit.source: All the data that is backed up is compressed and encrypted before being transferred.
trans-unit.target: All the data that is backed up is compressed and encrypted before being transferred.

trans-unit.source: You can expect 30-40% compression benefits depending on the type of data being backed up.
trans-unit.target: You can expect 30-40% compression benefits depending on the type of data being backed up.

trans-unit.source: Recovery
trans-unit.target: Recovery

trans-unit.source: **Q1. How many recoveries can I perform on the data that is backed up to Azure?**
trans-unit.target: **Q1. How many recoveries can I perform on the data that is backed up to Azure?**

trans-unit.source: There is no limit on the number of recoveries from Azure Backup.
trans-unit.target: There is no limit on the number of recoveries from Azure Backup.

trans-unit.source: **Q2. Do I have to pay for the egress traffic from Azure data center during recoveries?**
trans-unit.target: **Q2. Do I have to pay for the egress traffic from Azure data center during recoveries?**

trans-unit.source: No.
trans-unit.target: No.

trans-unit.source: Your recoveries are free and you are not charged for the egress traffic.
trans-unit.target: Your recoveries are free and you are not charged for the egress traffic.

trans-unit.source: Security
trans-unit.target: Security

trans-unit.source: **Q1. Is the data sent to Azure encrypted?**
trans-unit.target: **Q1. Is the data sent to Azure encrypted?**

trans-unit.source: Yes.
trans-unit.target: Yes.

trans-unit.source: Data is encrypted on the on-premises server/client/SCDPM machine using AES256 and the data is sent over a secure HTTPS link.
trans-unit.target: Data is encrypted on the on-premises server/client/SCDPM machine using AES256 and the data is sent over a secure HTTPS link.

trans-unit.source: **Q2. Is the backup data on Azure encrypted as well?**
trans-unit.target: **Q2. Is the backup data on Azure encrypted as well?**

trans-unit.source: Yes.
trans-unit.target: Yes.

trans-unit.source: The data which is sent to Azure remains encrypted (at rest).
trans-unit.target: The data which is sent to Azure remains encrypted (at rest).

trans-unit.source: Microsoft does not decrypt the backup data at any point.
trans-unit.target: Microsoft does not decrypt the backup data at any point.

trans-unit.source: **Q3. What is the minimum length of encryption key used to encrypt backup data?**
trans-unit.target: **Q3. What is the minimum length of encryption key used to encrypt backup data?**

trans-unit.source: The encryption key should be at least 16 characters.
trans-unit.target: The encryption key should be at least 16 characters.

trans-unit.source: **Q4. What happens if I misplace the encryption key? Can I recover the data (or) can Microsoft recover the data?**
trans-unit.target: **Q4. What happens if I misplace the encryption key? Can I recover the data (or) can Microsoft recover the data?**

trans-unit.source: The key used to encrypt the backup data is present only on the customer premises.
trans-unit.target: The key used to encrypt the backup data is present only on the customer premises.

trans-unit.source: Microsoft does not maintain a copy in Azure and does not have any access to the key.
trans-unit.target: Microsoft does not maintain a copy in Azure and does not have any access to the key.

trans-unit.source: If the customer misplaces the key, Microsoft cannot recover the backup data.
trans-unit.target: If the customer misplaces the key, Microsoft cannot recover the backup data.

trans-unit.source: Backup cache
trans-unit.target: Backup cache

trans-unit.source: How can I change the cache location specified for the Azure Backup agent?
trans-unit.target: How can I change the cache location specified for the Azure Backup agent?

trans-unit.source: Stop the OBEngine by executing the below command in an elevated command prompt:
trans-unit.target: Stop the OBEngine by executing the below command in an elevated command prompt:

trans-unit.source: Copy the cache space folder to a different drive with sufficient space.
trans-unit.target: Copy the cache space folder to a different drive with sufficient space.

trans-unit.source: We recommend you copy the files from the cache space folder instead of moving them; the original cache space can be removed after confirming that the backups are working with the new cache space.
trans-unit.target: We recommend you copy the files from the cache space folder instead of moving them; the original cache space can be removed after confirming that the backups are working with the new cache space.

trans-unit.source: Update following registry entries with the path to new cache space folder:
trans-unit.target: Update following registry entries with the path to new cache space folder:

trans-unit.source: Start the OBEngine by executing the below command in an elevated command prompt:
trans-unit.target: Start the OBEngine by executing the below command in an elevated command prompt:

trans-unit.source: Once the backups happen successfully with the new cache location, you can remove the original cache folder.
trans-unit.target: Once the backups happen successfully with the new cache location, you can remove the original cache folder.

trans-unit.source: test
trans-unit.target: test
